p: The regulation of SP-A is dependent on cytokines, in particular on TNF-α. TNF-α is capable of altering the mRNA level of SP-A via the phosphorylation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinases [ 46, 47]. As a consequence, an increased TNF-α level during an S. aureus infection hampers the function of SP-A. It is well known that S. aureus infections lead to a high release of TNF-α, in particular originating from immune cells, such as macrophages. Yet, TNF-α expression was not increased upon IAV infection in immune cells within the present experimental setting.
